title: 50 AI Prompts for Teachers
subtitle: Ready-to-use prompts that save 10+ hours per week on lesson planning, grading, and parent communication

blocks.text: Keep it simple. Copy any prompt, add your specific details, and paste into your preferred AI assistant (ChatGPT, Claude, Copilot, etc.). Each prompt includes safety guardrails and follows teacher-tested patterns.

blocks.title: 2-minute start
blocks.text: Pick one prompt from Parent Communication (page 4). Try it with a real scenario. See the difference quality prompting makes.
All prompts follow the PASTE framework: Purpose-Audience-Scope-Tone-Evidence. This ensures consistent, professional results every time.
Before using any AI prompt in teaching, follow these non-negotiable safety practices:

items: Never paste student names - use initials or 'the student'
Remove any identifying details (school, location, family info)
Always review AI output before sending or sharing
Keep sensitive conversations offline (behavioural concerns, family issues)
Check your school's AI policy before using these prompts

blocks.title: Privacy first
blocks.text: AI assistants learn from your inputs. Never share confidential student information, assessment data, or private family details.
Transform awkward parent conversations into clear, supportive messages. Each prompt includes email and SMS variants.

blocks.title: Prompt #1: Positive behaviour update
blocks.text: Write a brief, warm message to [student's parent/guardian] about [specific positive behaviour]. The message should: highlight the exact behaviour, explain why it matters for learning, keep it under 100 words, use an encouraging but not over-the-top tone. Context: [brief situation]. Format as [email/SMS].

blocks.title: Prompt #2: Missing homework follow-up
blocks.text: Draft a non-judgmental message to [student's parent/guardian] about incomplete homework. The message should: state the facts clearly, offer support rather than blame, suggest one practical next step, maintain a collaborative tone. Missing work: [assignment details]. Keep under 75 words for SMS, 150 for email.

blocks.title: Prompt #3: Attendance concern
blocks.text: Create a caring message to [parent/guardian] about attendance patterns. Focus on: recent absence pattern without listing specific dates, how it impacts learning, offering support, requesting a brief conversation. Pattern: [brief description]. Tone: concerned but supportive. Format: [email/SMS].

blocks.title: Prompt #4: Academic progress celebration
blocks.text: Write an uplifting message celebrating [student's] academic improvement. Include: specific area of growth, what the student did differently, how this helps their learning, brief encouragement for continued progress. Progress: [specific details]. Keep tone genuine, not overly effusive.

blocks.title: Prompt #5: General check-in
blocks.text: Draft a warm check-in message to [parent/guardian] about [student's] overall wellbeing. Touch on: recent observations about mood/engagement, any small concerns or positives, invitation for parent input, offer of support. Observations: [brief notes]. Tone: caring, open, non-alarming.

blocks.title: Message timing
blocks.text: Send positive messages immediately. For concerns, wait 24 hours after drafting to review with fresh eyes.

blocks.title: Prompt #6: Event invitation
blocks.text: Create an engaging invitation for [school event]. Include: event purpose and benefits, key logistics (date, time, location), what to expect, simple RSVP method, warm closing. Event: [details]. Tone: welcoming and informative.

blocks.title: Prompt #7: Classroom volunteer request
blocks.text: Write a friendly request for parent volunteers. Specify: activity requiring help, time commitment, no special skills needed, how it benefits students, easy sign-up process. Activity: [details]. Emphasize that any amount of help is appreciated.

blocks.title: Prompt #8: End-of-term wrap-up
blocks.text: Compose a reflective end-of-term message highlighting [student's] growth. Include: 2-3 specific improvements, challenges they overcame, strengths to build on next term, appreciation for parent support. Growth areas: [specific examples].

blocks.title: Prompt #9: Quick daily update
blocks.text: Create a brief daily update for [parent/guardian] about [student's] day. Mention: one positive moment, learning highlight, any minor notes, tomorrow's focus. Today's highlights: [brief notes]. Keep under 50 words.

blocks.title: Prompt #10: Resource sharing
blocks.text: Share a helpful learning resource with [parent/guardian]. Explain: why this resource suits [student], how to use it at home, expected time commitment, offer to discuss further. Resource: [name and brief description]. Tone: helpful, not prescriptive.
Cut lesson prep time in half with these structured planning prompts. Perfect for new concepts, review sessions, and differentiated instruction.

blocks.title: Prompt #11: Lesson plan scaffold
blocks.text: Create a 45-minute lesson plan for [subject] on [topic]. Include: clear learning objective, 3-part structure (intro/main/plenary), differentiation for 3 ability levels, 2 formative assessment checkpoints, required resources. Grade level: [X]. Class context: [brief description].

blocks.title: Prompt #12: Differentiated activities
blocks.text: Design 3 versions of the same activity for [topic], suitable for: below grade level (needs support), at grade level (independent work), above grade level (extension challenge). Subject: [X]. Core concept: [specific learning goal]. Time: [X minutes].

blocks.title: Prompt #13: Assessment questions
blocks.text: Generate 10 assessment questions for [topic] at [grade level]. Mix: 3 recall questions, 4 application questions, 3 analysis/evaluation questions. Include answer guide and common misconceptions to watch for. Topic: [specific concept].

blocks.title: Prompt #14: Cross-curricular connections
blocks.text: Suggest 5 ways to connect [main subject topic] with other curriculum areas. Focus on: natural links that enhance understanding, practical activities students can do, real-world applications. Main topic: [X]. Grade: [X]. Available subjects: [list].

blocks.title: Prompt #15: Starter activities
blocks.text: Create 5 engaging 10-minute lesson starters for [topic]. Vary the approaches: visual hook, quick game, real-world connection, recap quiz, prediction activity. Requirements: no prep needed, gets all students involved. Topic: [specific area].

blocks.title: Batch processing
blocks.text: Generate multiple lesson starters at once, then mix and match throughout the week. Saves 30+ minutes of daily prep.

blocks.title: Prompt #16: Review session design
blocks.text: Plan an engaging review session for [topic/unit]. Include: key concepts to reinforce, interactive recap activities, common mistake corrections, confidence-building elements, final quick assessment. Duration: [X minutes]. Students struggled with: [areas].

blocks.title: Prompt #17: Homework alternatives
blocks.text: Design 5 homework alternatives for [topic] that work for diverse family situations. Options should: take 15-20 minutes, require minimal resources, allow for family involvement, connect to real life. Topic: [X]. Grade: [X].

blocks.title: Prompt #18: Extension activities
blocks.text: Create challenging extension tasks for fast finishers studying [topic]. Activities should: deepen understanding, work independently, take 10-15 minutes, require no additional marking. Include 3 options with brief instructions.

blocks.title: Prompt #19: Vocabulary introduction
blocks.text: Design activities to introduce 5-7 key vocabulary terms for [topic]. Include: memorable ways to present each word, simple definition strategies, practice activities, assessment ideas. Target words: [list]. Grade: [X].

blocks.title: Prompt #20: Project scaffolding
blocks.text: Break down a [duration] project on [topic] into manageable steps. Include: weekly milestones, assessment checkpoints, support resources, common pitfalls to avoid, final presentation format. Project goal: [brief description].
Generate meaningful, personalised feedback that helps students grow. These prompts ensure consistency while maintaining authenticity.

blocks.title: Prompt #21: Strengths-based feedback
blocks.text: Write encouraging feedback for [student] in [subject]. Focus on: specific strengths demonstrated, growth since last assessment, next steps that build on strengths, maintain positive tone throughout. Recent work: [brief description]. Keep to 50-75 words.

blocks.title: Prompt #22: Improvement feedback
blocks.text: Create constructive feedback for [subject] work that needs improvement. Include: what was done well first, specific area to develop, practical next step, encouragement to keep trying. Avoid negative language. Work quality: [brief, objective description].

blocks.title: Prompt #23: Report card comments
blocks.text: Write a balanced report comment for [subject]. Cover: academic progress this term, key strengths, one area for development, attitude towards learning, suggestion for home support. Character count: 200-250. Overall performance: [brief summary].

blocks.title: Prompt #24: Self-assessment prompts
blocks.text: Create 5 age-appropriate self-reflection questions for [grade level] students about their [subject] learning. Questions should: encourage honest reflection, focus on process not just outcome, be specific to recent work, help identify next steps.

blocks.title: Prompt #25: Peer feedback frameworks
blocks.text: Design a simple peer feedback structure for [activity type]. Include: 2 positive observation prompts, 1 suggestion prompt, sentence starters for shy students, guidelines for respectful feedback. Activity: [brief description].

blocks.title: Evidence shows
blocks.text: Students retain feedback better when it's specific, actionable, and balanced. Generic praise ('good work') has minimal impact on learning.

blocks.title: Prompt #26: Growth tracking comments
blocks.text: Document [student's] learning journey in [subject] over this term. Highlight: where they started, key breakthroughs, persistent challenges, improved skills, evidence of growth. Keep encouraging and forward-looking.

blocks.title: Prompt #27: Goal-setting feedback
blocks.text: Help [student] set realistic learning goals for [subject]. Based on current performance, suggest: 1 skill-building goal, 1 confidence goal, 1 challenge goal. Make goals specific and achievable within [timeframe]. Current level: [brief description].

blocks.title: Prompt #28: Portfolio reflection
blocks.text: Guide [student] to reflect on their portfolio/work collection. Prompt them to: identify their best work and explain why, note biggest learning moments, spot patterns in their progress, set one focus area for next term.

blocks.title: Prompt #29: Effort recognition
blocks.text: Acknowledge [student's] effort and persistence in [challenging area]. Focus on: specific behaviours that show effort, strategies they used, how persistence led to improvement, encourage continued resilience. Recent example: [brief description].

blocks.title: Prompt #30: Conference preparation
blocks.text: Prepare talking points for parent conference about [student]. Cover: academic strengths, social development, areas needing support, specific examples, suggested home strategies, celebration of progress. Keep balanced and solution-focused.
Navigate sensitive conversations with care and professionalism. These prompts help you communicate concerns while maintaining positive relationships.

blocks.title: Prompt #31: Positive behaviour note
blocks.text: Share a positive behaviour observation about [student] with their family. Highlight: specific positive action, why it matters, how it helped others/learning, brief encouragement for more of the same. Keep warm but professional. Recent example: [brief description].

blocks.title: Prompt #32: Gentle behaviour concern
blocks.text: Address a minor behaviour concern with [parent/guardian]. Use: factual observation (no labels), impact on learning, request for support, offer collaborative approach. Avoid blame or judgment. Behaviour: [objective description]. Keep solution-focused.

blocks.title: Prompt #33: Social skills celebration
blocks.text: Celebrate [student's] social growth or friendship skills. Mention: specific social behaviour observed, positive impact on class community, how it shows personal growth, encouragement to continue. Example: [brief, positive situation].

blocks.title: Prompt #34: Emotional check-in
blocks.text: Craft a caring check-in about [student's] emotional wellbeing. Include: gentle observation about mood/engagement changes, reassurance and support, invitation for student/parent input, offer of help. Keep non-diagnostic and supportive.

blocks.title: Prompt #35: Transition support
blocks.text: Help [student] prepare for [upcoming change/transition]. Create guidance that: acknowledges their feelings, explains what to expect, offers practical coping strategies, reassures about support available. Transition: [brief description].

blocks.title: Language that helps
blocks.text: Use 'I noticed...' instead of 'X is being...'. Focus on actions and impact, not character judgments.

blocks.title: Prompt #36: Friendship navigation
blocks.text: Address friendship concerns with [student] sensitively. Provide: acknowledgment of their feelings, practical friendship skills, strategies for specific situations, reassurance about adult support. Keep age-appropriate and hopeful.

blocks.title: Prompt #37: Confidence building
blocks.text: Support [student] who lacks confidence in [area]. Offer: recognition of their courage in trying, specific strengths to build on, small achievable next steps, reassurance about learning process. Area of concern: [brief description].

blocks.title: Prompt #38: Resilience recognition
blocks.text: Acknowledge [student's] resilience during [challenging situation]. Highlight: specific coping strategies they used, growth you've observed, qualities that helped them, encouragement for continued strength. Keep encouraging and specific.

blocks.title: Prompt #39: Classroom community
blocks.text: Help [student] understand their role in classroom community. Explain: how their actions affect others, positive contributions they make, ways to be an even better community member, appreciation for their efforts.

blocks.title: Prompt #40: Motivation support
blocks.text: Re-engage [student] who seems disinterested in [subject/activity]. Use: curiosity about their perspective, connection to their interests, offer of choice/control, reminder of past successes, collaborative problem-solving approach.
Perfect for multilingual classrooms and fine-tuning your communication style. These prompts help bridge language gaps and adjust tone for different audiences.

blocks.title: Prompt #41: Simple language conversion
blocks.text: Rewrite this message using simpler language suitable for [target audience]: [original message]. Keep the same meaning but: use shorter sentences, choose common words, explain any necessary jargon, maintain respectful tone.

blocks.title: Prompt #42: Formal to friendly
blocks.text: Convert this formal message to a warm, friendly tone while keeping it professional: [message text]. Adjust: word choices, sentence structure, overall warmth, maintain all important information. Target audience: [parents/students/colleagues].

blocks.title: Prompt #43: Multilingual support
blocks.text: Provide this message in both English and [language], with cultural sensitivity notes: [message]. Ensure: accurate translation, cultural appropriateness, same level of formality, any cultural context needed for understanding.

blocks.title: Prompt #44: Age-appropriate adjustment
blocks.text: Adapt this explanation for [age group]: [content]. Make it: developmentally appropriate, engaging for their interests, easy to understand, include relatable examples. Original explanation: [text].

blocks.title: Prompt #45: Sensitive topic language
blocks.text: Help me communicate about [sensitive topic] with [audience] using careful, supportive language. Provide: gentle but clear wording, age-appropriate explanations, reassuring tone, practical next steps. Context: [brief situation].

blocks.title: Cultural bridge-building
blocks.text: When working with multilingual families, always ask about preferred communication styles and language preferences. Respect varies by culture.

blocks.title: Prompt #46: Urgent tone adjustment
blocks.text: Rewrite this message to sound less urgent/alarming: [message]. Keep: all factual information, need for response, professional tone. Remove: alarming language, pressure, anxiety-inducing words. Make it informative but calm.

blocks.title: Prompt #47: Encouraging reframe
blocks.text: Reframe this message to sound more encouraging: [original text]. Transform: challenges into growth opportunities, problems into learning chances, criticism into support, while maintaining honesty about the situation.

blocks.title: Prompt #48: Professional polish
blocks.text: Polish this draft for professional communication: [draft text]. Improve: clarity, grammar, tone consistency, structure, while preserving the original meaning and personal touch. Audience: [specify].

blocks.title: Prompt #49: Quick text alternatives
blocks.text: Create 3 different versions of this message with varying lengths: [original]. Provide: detailed version (email), medium version (note home), brief version (quick text). Keep core message consistent across all versions.

blocks.title: Prompt #50: Voice consistency check
blocks.text: Review these messages for consistent voice and tone: [message 1], [message 2], [message 3]. Ensure: same level of formality, consistent warmth, similar sentence structure, unified professional image. Suggest adjustments if needed.
Master these frameworks to create your own effective prompts. The PASTE pattern works for any teaching communication scenario.

blocks.title: PASTE Framework
blocks.text: Purpose: What do you want the AI to create? Audience: Who will read/use this? Scope: How detailed/long should it be? Tone: What mood/style is appropriate? Evidence: What specific details should be included?

blocks.title: Safety Template
blocks.text: Always include: 'Do not include any student names, identifying details, or confidential information. Keep language professional and supportive. Focus on [specific area] without making judgments about character.'

do: Be specific about word count limits
Ask for multiple options or versions
Specify the exact tone you need
dont: Use vague instructions like 'make it good'
Expect perfect results on first try
Forget to review and personalise outputs

blocks.title: Template creation
blocks.text: Turn your most-used prompts into templates. Save them with placeholder text like [STUDENT NAME] and [TOPIC] for quick customisation.

tearsheet.heading: 12 Highest-Impact Prompts
bullets: Positive behaviour update - Build home-school connections
Missing homework follow-up - Stay supportive, not punitive
Lesson plan scaffold - Cut prep time in half
Simple language conversion - Reach all families
Gentle behaviour concern - Address issues early
Quick daily update - Keep parents informed
Differentiated activities - Meet every learner's needs
Report card comments - Balance honesty with encouragement
Emotional check-in - Support whole child development
Professional polish - Maintain consistent communication quality
